We've now exhausted online research options for all 9,000+ public library systems that we set out to research, and we successfully collected both a website and the method of board-member selection (appointed versus elected) for 7,000+ of them!

For every public library system in the US, we attempted to find their official website & their method of selection for new library governance board members (appointed versus elected) as well as 6 other key pieces of information.+

Anyway, it's appropriate on this day to honor Martin AND Coretta alongside the movement that made both of them possible.
Those are treasures.

When I was a young person, I came to know Coretta because she was active in the South African Anti-Apartheid movement. It was only later that I even connected her to Martin. She was outspoken in speaking out and organizing against Apartheid.

She returned to the sanitation workers' picket line 4 days after his murder! Crucial to adding "full employment" to the Fed's mandate. Probably the most important post-73 economic justice activist in the US, she said, "This nation has never honestly dealt with the question of a peacetime economy.”
Perhaps some of the letters she received from your grandmother would be in Coretta's archives?
Coretta was also a brilliant musician. She was a soprano singer and violinist. She used her musical skills to fundraise. www.classicfm.com/discover-mus...
yes. she archived his life and pushed for the Holiday.
King was radicalized by his future wife early on. Perhaps more people should take this into account.

He tells her that he understands though that capitalism is not going to disappear overnight. What the letter shows to me is how he took Coretta as an intellectual equal from the start and it shows me that she was already a socialist when she met him.

Bellamy predicts that the US would be a socialist society with things like free medical care, unemployment insurance, etc. Martin writes Coretta a letter in which he talks about how much Bellamy impressed him. Says that his ideas are in line with Bellamy.

Coretta sent Martin Looking Backward, by Edward Bellamy, with an inscription saying she would like to know what he thought about the book. Considered one of the first science fiction books it focused on what America would be like in the year 2000.
I like to revisit to this letter King wrote to Coretta when they were still dating. kinginstitute.stanford.edu/king-papers/...

That’s my ultimate take on the book. It’s a bad book, because Isaacson isn’t up to the task. 

He should stick to writing comforting “Great Men of History” biographies of the deceased. 

He doesn’t have the reporting or analytic chops to contextualize large social events as they are unfolding.

Isaacson’s model of society is that history is written by unrestrained, risk-taking geniuses. 

That’s the type of biography he set out to write. 

He doesn’t much like Musk, because Musk won’t fit into the archetype. 

But it’s the only story Isaacson is equipped to tell.

The final three chapters are an attempt to rehabilitate Musk-the-genius. And it’s just pathetic view-from-Musk pablum. 

Musk wonders “if it’s worth spending that much time thinking about Twitter. Sure I could probably make it the biggest financial institution in the world. But [what about AI?]”

P. 488-494 you can really tell that Isaacson desperately wishes the Twitter deal hadn’t happened. 

He wants to write about the car and rocket guy. The rich guy who is taking risks and building the future! He doesn’t want to write about the plutocrat with no impulse control and no clue.

It’s been a terrific experience reading these abolitionist life stories with a community of like-minded folks. Today, 200 years after William's birth, I am thinking of the Crafts and what their lives meant in their time and in ours.

So, why remember William (born 200 years ago) and Ellen Craft? The stories of anti-slavery abolitionists (particularly formerly enslaved people) are so compelling and important in their own right. They also help us to think about the many emancipatory struggles in which we are engaged today.

We recently read Woo’s book and talked about the Crafts in the Life Stories of Anti-Slavery Abolitionists reading group organized by @@2481. We’ll be reading our sixth and final book of 2023 (a biography of William Still) on November 19.

bookshop.org/p/books/vigi...

The story of Ellen and William Craft is told in masterful fashion by Ilyon Woo in her recent book Master Slave Husband Wife: An Epic Journey From Slavery to Freedom. It’s a terrific read.

bookshop.org/p/books/mast...

The abolitionist William Craft was born 200 years ago today.* Who was he, and why should we remember him?

*Wikipedia and other sites list September 25, 1824 as Craft’s birthday, but his biographer Ilyon Woo gives it as 9/22/1823 on page 31 (see image) of her recent book (more on which below!).

I do! It's a bit of an obsession for me to read about all of the ways that people are trying to do digital preservation.
Think for example about how many potential important documents have been lost to floppy disks alone.

As an archivist, I am also very concerned about vanishing data online. It used to be that the worries were mainly about link rot, the obsolescence of various data storage mechanisms, etc... but now gotta deal with the actual tech companies themselves...
I spoke to someone about this recently who is in the preservation and tech space. He said  big tech is actively wiping a lot of past data. It's a real thing.

Something very strange is happening to the Web. Finding something from the past on search engines is eroding. Atemporality replaced by an immediate, constantly vanishing, consumerist hyper-present. What we thought was an infinite Borges-ian library turning into Amazon checkout with a ticking clock…

Remember when we lost somewhere around 60-75% of silent films because they were treated like disposable commodities instead of history and/or art?

That’s where we are again, right now, in multiple mediums, isn’t it?
